description.narrative: Supporting community level action to conserve biodiversity, reverse land degradation and mitigates climate change in priority landscape across India
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: 5th Operational phase of the Small Grants Programme (SGP)

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

Outcome 11 Panchayats local self governments incorporate improved management practices into village level planning for community managed landscapes and seascapes enhancing mosaics of landuses and improving biodiversity conservation
Number of community led tools and methodologies developed for biodiversity mapping monitoring and valuation

comment.narrative: In 16 projects Sujagriti Sarjana GSMT THA SRIDA KFI Gram Sudhar Samiti CONARE PPSS BRASS etc the grantees are promoting Biodiversity Registers Participatory Rural Appraisals in building and mapping the priority use of local biodiversity setting up biodiversity gardens for conservation of seeds and fruits setting up herbariums better extraction and value addition for market links enterprise development for improved livelihoods

In 16 projects Sujagriti Sarjana GSMT THA SRIDA KFI Gram Sudhar Samiti CONARE PPSS BRASS etc the grantees are promoting Biodiversity Registers Participatory Rural Appraisals in building and mapping the priority use of local biodiversity setting up biodiversity gardens for conservation of seeds and fruits setting up herbariums better extraction and value addition for market links enterprise development for improved livelihoods

description.narrative: Number of new branding geographic indicators certified agrobased products developed in the project sites

comment.narrative: 5 by project end

Nearly 07 Brands created through different partners ie 1 Vechur Cow ghee and urine and other medicinal products created 2 KFI has promoted NTFPs into marketable products and branded them 3 Brown Rice organic wheat based products by Sarjana and Sujagriti and also 4 three types of Millets by Arambha and Nirman 5 Desert Honey by Samrthak 6 Oils and medicated hair Oils by SEE 7 Bamboo products by BDT More partners like Sujagrati Lotus TIDE Samekit SESA SYSS and are also getting into registering products
5 by project end

Nearly 07 Brands created through different partners ie 1 Vechur Cow ghee and urine and other medicinal products created 2 KFI has promoted NTFPs into marketable products and branded them 3 Brown Rice organic wheat based products by Sarjana and Sujagriti and also 4 three types of Millets by Arambha and Nirman 5 Desert Honey by Samrthak 6 Oils and medicated hair Oils by SEE 7 Bamboo products by BDT More partners like Sujagrati Lotus TIDE Samekit SESA SYSS and are also getting into registering products

description.narrative: Number of panchayats incorporating sustainable management practices into village level resource use plans

comment.narrative: 30 by year 4

43 Panchayats incorporated sustainable management practices into village level resource use planning by making the communities a part of the decisionmaking by allotting revenue land for setting up check dams water harvesting systems developing grazing lands and fodder plots mangroves restoration cookstoves honey collection etc GSMT MPSS GVNML Kheti Virasat Shashwat CCD We Care Society Samekit CORE and Sujagriti have used funds from Government Agriculture and MNREGA funds through Panchayats
30 by year 4

43 Panchayats incorporated sustainable management practices into village level resource use planning by making the communities a part of the decisionmaking by allotting revenue land for setting up check dams water harvesting systems developing grazing lands and fodder plots mangroves restoration cookstoves honey collection etc GSMT MPSS GVNML Kheti Virasat Shashwat CCD We Care Society Samekit CORE and Sujagriti have used funds from Government Agriculture and MNREGA funds through Panchayats

description.narrative: Number of rare and threatened domesticated cultivars livestock varieties brought under focused conservation practices in the project sites

comment.narrative: At least 5

07 rare and threatened agro animal and plant varieties conserved ie Guggul and in THA project 08 Medicinal Plant Mangroves varieties like Avicenna alba Avicenna Marina
3 salt resistant Rice Varieties like Malaboti Dudheswar Swanamasuri and Jhingashal Vechur Cow Vembur Sheep and protection of Sacred Groves
At least 5

07 rare and threatened agro animal and plant varieties conserved ie Guggul and in THA project 08 Medicinal Plant Mangroves varieties like Avicenna alba Avicenna Marina
3 salt resistant Rice Varieties like Malaboti Dudheswar Swanamasuri and Jhingashal Vechur Cow Vembur Sheep and protection of Sacred Groves

description.narrative: Number of womens groups formed strengthened for planning and executing of sustainable natural resource management

comment.narrative: 50 This is based on the past experience of the SGP and shall be firmed up after individual grantees are identified
100 This is based on the past experience of the SGP and shall be firmed up after individual grantees are identified

A total of 679 Women Self Help Groups have been formed strengthened comprising 13795 women members who do regular savings have opened bank accounts and accessed credit to generate substantial cofinancing Nearly 391 803 USD savings have happened in projects and they have sourced nearly 590000 USD as loans and grants in projects
To ensure sustainability in most of SGP projects the main focus has been on establishing strengthening the institutional structure and empowering the communities in managing the projects themselves
100 This is based on the past experience of the SGP and shall be firmed up after individual grantees are identified

A total of 679 Women Self Help Groups have been formed strengthened comprising 13795 women members who do regular savings have opened bank accounts and accessed credit to generate substantial cofinancing Nearly 391 803 USD savings have happened in projects and they have sourced nearly 590000 USD as loans and grants in projects
To ensure sustainability in most of SGP projects the main focus has been on establishing strengthening the institutional structure and empowering the communities in managing the projects themselves

description.narrative: Outcome 21 Appropriate energy efficient technologies result in emission reductions
of tonnes of CO2e emission reductions achieved through adoption of energy efficient technologies

comment.narrative: 150000 metric tonnes per year
225000 tonnes of CO2e emission reductions over 3 years

Against a budget of US 2224 million for climate change portfolio a commitment of US 1110 million has been done through 27 projects out of a total of 77 approved so far
A range of simple and lowcost EE technologies relating to briquetting units waste recycling biomass driers improved cookstoves and biogas have been adopted
More than 79450 MTs of CO2 emission checked through a range of alternate energy and EE technologies adopted by Vivekananda Trust Sarjana SESS CORE Muskan Jyoti IIPM TIDE Shashwat and other partners
Nearly 1600 improved and fuelefficient cookstoves constructed 900 alone by Vivekananda Trust 200 by Mahatma Phule 150 by Shashwat 200 by SYSS 45 by Earthwatch 35 by SSE and 30 by Manuvikasa and rest by others
82 Biogas units set up in more than 20 projects 31 by Peekay Tree 22 by Friends of Doon Society 20 by VSK and 09 by Chhatrasal Two different models floating dome and Ferrocement have been tried
Sujagriti SSYS and Sarjana were trained in the appropriate cookstove technologies at the CEESAIL project site in Gonda GSMT visited Arti to adopt cookstove designs Nagarika Trust and We Care Society adopted the cookstove technologies from TIDE
SYSS and Shashwat made visits to MGIRI to learn about new solar based technologies and adopting into the SGP projects The trainings are happening for communities and NGOs with service providers
ZIRCORD has taken up with 04 Panchayats the setting up of biomass briquettes based on ricehusk Also CCD and Sarjana are adopting low cost technologies of biobriquetting
A special meeting was organized with BAREFOOT POWER for accessing and sharing their technologies Partners like SYSS Kurseong Disha GVNML and VSK are adopting the RE technologies in their projects
SSE is exploring the opportunities for putting up microhydro unit under the project More impacts of CO2 emission reduction will emerge close to completion of the project activities
225000 tonnes of CO2e emission reductions over 3 years

SSE is exploring the opportunities for putting up microhydro unit under the project More impacts of CO2 emission reduction will emerge close to completion of the project activities

description.narrative: of tonnes CO2e emissions reduced through adoption of renewable energy technologies at local level

comment.narrative: 50000 metric tonnes per year
12277 tonnes of CO2e by end of project

7000 tons of CO2 emissions are being reduced through renewable energy technologies like solar energy solar lanterns solar driers for multiple applications including fish drying power generating water mills 16 and Micro Hydels 01 In learning from SGP SAIL project has done 250 solar lanterns in a business case and two street lights installed
In NERD two women led SHGs formed for laying out two biogas units to produce electricity
12277 tonnes of CO2e by end of project

7000 tons of CO2 emissions are being reduced through renewable energy technologies like solar energy solar lanterns solar driers for multiple applications including fish drying power generating water mills 16 and Micro Hydels 01 In learning from SGP SAIL project has done 250 solar lanterns in a business case and two street lights installed
In NERD two women led SHGs formed for laying out two biogas units to produce electricity

description.narrative: of women involved through SHGs in investments for emissions reductions

comment.narrative: to be assessed in the initial phase of the project
10 increase by end of year 2 and 20 increase by end of year 4

Through projects like TIDE NERD Sujagrati GVSS and Disha efforts are being made to encourage the partners to access the emission reduction technologies through investments from their savings
Presently about 5 of SHGs are making investments in adoption of such technologies through their savings Women entrepreneurs have sourced small technologies eg solar lanterns solar torches and mobile phone chargers with small penlight cells
10 increase by end of year 2 and 20 increase by end of year 4

Through projects like TIDE NERD Sujagrati GVSS and Disha efforts are being made to encourage the partners to access the emission reduction technologies through investments from their savings
Presently about 5 of SHGs are making investments in adoption of such technologies through their savings Women entrepreneurs have sourced small technologies eg solar lanterns solar torches and mobile phone chargers with small penlight cells

description.narrative: Outcome 31 Improved enabling environment at the panchayat level agricultural sector improves management functionality and cover of agroecosystems in ASAR LD1
No of hectares of dry agricultural lands brought under SLM with improved vegetative cover

comment.narrative: 70000 hectares

Nearly 42000 hectares of land brought under sustainable management through 15 projects Against an allocation of US 366833 a commitment of US 264636 has been done
Majority of the projects are with the poorest of the poor and with PVTGs Particularly Vulnerable Tribal Groups in the remote areas and are in line with the national priorities eg Spandan Paramparagat CHARDEP GSS WEEDS Nishwarth and Dharti are all by the protected areas
Under GVSS project 3 large size canal bunds and under Vruksh Prem 2 checkdams were constructed and waste land brought under additional cultivation resulting in increased income of farmers by 34 times 35 hectares of degradedwaste land brought under additional cultivation in Dausa and BandiKui Districts situated on the foothills of Aravali mountain range in Rajasthan State 9 hectares of fodder land brought under additional grazing in GVNML project in Rajasthan through locally devised Chauka systems of rainwater harvesting More than 57 fodder plots developed by CONARE in Andhra Pradesh State linking with Forage Department Hyderabad Ministry of Agriculture More than 27000 mangrove plantations made in 25 hectares of land area by PPSS Machlipatnam Andhra Pradesh
Six project partners Conare SYSS GVNML Mahila Haat MNTN and Chhatrasal developed fodder plots to link up with the project activities More than 400 ha land development actions undertaken by Manuvikasa 560 ha of rice cultivation done by Sarjana 600 ha millets by Paryavaraniya Vikas 450 ha by SRIDA through demonstrations on minor millets and Jowar Sujagriti has brought 1700 ha area under cultivation through earthen bunds with spillways also called dor bandi
61 Feeding Troughs set up to divert cattle from free grazing to stall fed conditions and to reduce burden on forests Agreements done with beneficiaries that 2 of their animals will not be sent to forest for grazing
Peekay Tree Crops promoted 4 womens food processing units two tailoring units and two commercial scale protected agriculture farms 12 goat breeding rearing units one community marketing outlet one horticulture nursery and 15 quail farming units 20 family farms are supported with vegetable planting materials and 500 tree saplings
SESA PUPA PPSS MPSSS visited Fodder Institutes for accessing improved quality seeds 123 compost pits developed and linked to the slurry emanating from the biogas units set up under the project 20 at GVSS 3 at Friends of Doon Society 30 in SMS 50 in We Care Society SYSS and Mahila Haat have also developed simple pits for composting Planning started for increasing soil productivity on 1600 Ha in Muskan Jyoti
Three community institutions registered for managing the EcoPulpers by IIPM and nearly 150 water reduction has happened per day 400 litres per 1000 kgs of coffee pulping to earlier 7000 litres In the 3 centres during the last one year for 65 days of operation the reduction has been 3567000 litres of water With the successful impacts emerging the NGO is taking up a Full Scale GEF project
Nearly 23 wells constructed under the Jaldhara Schemes of the States In Gravis 4 tanks have been made of 300 cubic feet which are holding nearly 8000 litres 1 cu ft is 231 litres of water The life span of these units being 20 years the cost of water storage is 0003 paisa per litre
70000 hectares

Majority of the projects are with the poorest of the poor and with PVTGs Particularly Vulnerable Tribal Groups in the remote areas and are in line with the national priorities eg Spandan Paramparagat CHARDEP GSS WEEDS Nishwarth and Dharti are all by the protected areas
Under GVSS project 3 large size canal bunds and under Vruksh Prem 2 checkdams were constructed and waste land brought under additional cultivation resulting in increased income of farmers by 34 times 35 hectares of degradedwaste land brought under additional cultivation in Dausa and BandiKui Districts situated on the foothills of Aravali mountain range in Rajasthan State 9 hectares of fodder land brought under additional grazing in GVNML project in Rajasthan through locally devised Chauka systems of rainwater harvesting More than 57 fodder plots developed by CONARE in Andhra Pradesh State linking with Forage Department Hyderabad Ministry of Agriculture More than 27000 mangrove plantations made in 25 hectares of land area by PPSS Machlipatnam Andhra Pradesh
Six project partners Conare SYSS GVNML Mahila Haat MNTN and Chhatrasal developed fodder plots to link up with the project activities More than 400 ha land development actions undertaken by Manuvikasa 560 ha of rice cultivation done by Sarjana 600 ha millets by Paryavaraniya Vikas 450 ha by SRIDA through demonstrations on minor millets and Jowar Sujagriti has brought 1700 ha area under cultivation through earthen bunds with spillways also called dor bandi

Peekay Tree Crops promoted 4 womens food processing units two tailoring units and two commercial scale protected agriculture farms 12 goat breeding rearing units one community marketing outlet one horticulture nursery and 15 quail farming units 20 family farms are supported with vegetable planting materials and 500 tree saplings

Three community institutions registered for managing the EcoPulpers by IIPM and nearly 150 water reduction has happened per day 400 litres per 1000 kgs of coffee pulping to earlier 7000 litres In the 3 centres during the last one year for 65 days of operation the reduction has been 3567000 litres of water With the successful impacts emerging the NGO is taking up a Full Scale GEF project

description.narrative: Number of new and additional sources identified for leveraging investment replication for SLM across drylands in ASAR

comment.narrative: At least 10 new sources

As explained earlier projects have leveraged resources for land development and linked to MNREGA a Government of India initiative in dry land remote districts and Watershed funds More than 45 wells recharged in the area resulting into increased irrigation NGOs like MPSS Shashwat SRIDA GVSS GSMT SAMEKIT and Gram Sathi
Many Panchayats are linking MNREGA program within the villages in projects Panchayats are providing approvals for areas for plantations road construction Mahatma Phule SRIDA Kurseong Disha Nirman Samarthak and APOWA Mangroves PPSS formation of Biodiversity Management Committees Sujagriti Sarjana KFI and SYSS All these actions will set a platform for replication activities in the projects
More partners like Dharti SYSS Niswarth and Samekit are also developing similar links in the coming year
At least 10 new sources

As explained earlier projects have leveraged resources for land development and linked to MNREGA a Government of India initiative in dry land remote districts and Watershed funds More than 45 wells recharged in the area resulting into increased irrigation NGOs like MPSS Shashwat SRIDA GVSS GSMT SAMEKIT and Gram Sathi
Many Panchayats are linking MNREGA program within the villages in projects Panchayats are providing approvals for areas for plantations road construction Mahatma Phule SRIDA Kurseong Disha Nirman Samarthak and APOWA Mangroves PPSS formation of Biodiversity Management Committees Sujagriti Sarjana KFI and SYSS All these actions will set a platform for replication activities in the projects
More partners like Dharti SYSS Niswarth and Samekit are also developing similar links in the coming year

description.narrative: density of ground stocking in productive forest landscape in ASAR HFWG

comment.narrative: Ground stocking increased to 50

These are estimates made from the Mid Term reviews in projects and talks with locals The ground stock increase is taking place in 3 ways and Direct and Indirectly in all 3 ways
1 Plantations In 85 projects plantations are taking place due to multiple sources of financinginitiatives of SHGsForest Department and MNREGA In last 3 years more than 100000 plantations of trees with multiple species in projects
2 SWC Measures Due to introduction of soil and water conservation measures in projects the local biodiversity strengthening is already taking place As many of the works are in and around protected forest areas there is natural growth of the stock in place
3 Wood USE Savings Thirdly in several projects on improved cookstoves bio gas units have taken up in the periphery of protected areasreserved forests and this is leading to reduce pressures on forests the exact amount of saving can be gauged through each project
Ground stocking increased to 50

2 SWC Measures Due to introduction of soil and water conservation measures in projects the local biodiversity strengthening is already taking place As many of the works are in and around protected forest areas there is natural growth of the stock in place
3 Wood USE Savings Thirdly in several projects on improved cookstoves bio gas units have taken up in the periphery of protected areasreserved forests and this is leading to reduce pressures on forests the exact amount of saving can be gauged through each project

description.narrative: Outcome 41 Increased capacity of SGP stakeholders to diagnose and understand the complex and dynamic nature of global environmental problems and to develop local solutions
Increase in amount of cofunding for SGPIndia

comment.narrative: USD 5 million

US 482 million by NGOs CBOs US 50000 inkind technical contribution and 10000 in cash by UNDP US 400000 by private sector The progress so far is satisfactory and with the links established already with Wells for India AIRBUS Corporate Foundation JSW NMPB and others The target will be increased at the end of the project More contributions from the scaling up initiatives in projects will be much more and still 20 projects will be approved
USD 5 million

US 482 million by NGOs CBOs US 50000 inkind technical contribution and 10000 in cash by UNDP US 400000 by private sector The progress so far is satisfactory and with the links established already with Wells for India AIRBUS Corporate Foundation JSW NMPB and others The target will be increased at the end of the project More contributions from the scaling up initiatives in projects will be much more and still 20 projects will be approved

description.narrative: Number of new grants that replicate consolidated approaches BD CC LD

comment.narrative: Replication of consolidated approaches BD CC LD in at least 30 new grants by year 4

17 replication and scaling up projects have been taken up under all the 3 GEF thematic areas and operational zed This has been undertaken with the twin objectives of broadening the areas and technologies uptake from the project and partner institutions
The projects have shown greater promise access to government Schemes GEF benefits co financing and sustainable institution creation brand building business models The focus in GEF SGP is to create a niche through scaling up and make communities responsible and have greater ownerships skills and practices Many of the projects have already developed sustainable institutions as Producer Co and Cooperatives etc for long term sustainable development
Replication of consolidated approaches BD CC LD in at least 30 new grants by year 4

17 replication and scaling up projects have been taken up under all the 3 GEF thematic areas and operational zed This has been undertaken with the twin objectives of broadening the areas and technologies uptake from the project and partner institutions
The projects have shown greater promise access to government Schemes GEF benefits co financing and sustainable institution creation brand building business models The focus in GEF SGP is to create a niche through scaling up and make communities responsible and have greater ownerships skills and practices Many of the projects have already developed sustainable institutions as Producer Co and Cooperatives etc for long term sustainable development

description.narrative: Number natural resource based products developed by the GEF SGP partners linked to markets

comment.narrative: 25 numbers at present
75 products by project end

74 natural resource based products developed and linked to market through more than 35 projects Details of these projects are uploaded regularly on SGP website wwwsgpindiaorg Regular facilitation is done to establish market linkages for these products through 3 Green Haat Market Place events that have been put up in association with the Ministry of Environment Forest Climate Change and UNDP A consultant has been appointed to explore the possibilities of emarketing by assisting the NGOs to have test certifications and quality focus
75 products by project end

74 natural resource based products developed and linked to market through more than 35 projects Details of these projects are uploaded regularly on SGP website wwwsgpindiaorg Regular facilitation is done to establish market linkages for these products through 3 Green Haat Market Place events that have been put up in association with the Ministry of Environment Forest Climate Change and UNDP A consultant has been appointed to explore the possibilities of emarketing by assisting the NGOs to have test certifications and quality focus

description.narrative: Number of workshopslearning events conducted by the project by the GEF SGP partnersstakeholders

comment.narrative: GEF SGP partnersstakeholders

Workshops held in the beginning of year 1 to finalise the indicators and targets in the ME framework with all the stakeholders
Four learning events organised for key stakeholdersSGP grantees for achieving this outcome

With 10 GuidancecumCapacity Building workshops organized during the last year a total of 26 workshops have been organized from the start of the OP5 project
The NGOs were guided on the linkages to be established with government programs and financial institutions and how the GEFable impacts are to be viewed in the proposals and how the cofinancing is to be accessed and the calculations done for reporting purposes
During the workshops the learnings from other projects are shared resource persons Sector Experts guide them on new available technologies and how to access them More than 15 grantees have been linked up with various RE technologies Details given in the CB section
Exchange visits as learning exercises are arranged that help the NGOs to learn from each other on how to make a Producer Company improved cultivation practices of horticulture and polyhouse culture for better yields and income A visit of Lotus Society visited was arranged to Lok Panchayat to learn about setting up of SeedGran Banks Samarthak Samiti visited Yerala Society to link up their products for marketing
Experience of GVSS on exposure visit of their farmers to Agricultural Research Institute was shared with other NGOs and how the farmers benefitted by way of increased cultivation
GVNML was encouraged to promote for the improved income the local plant variety Kair for developing value added products like pickles which are in high demand in the neighbouring cities of Rajasthan
The NGOs are briefed on how to write reports to link up with Results Based Monitoring System how to do calculation of CO2 emission reduction from their operations and how to develop quality documentation including film making
A visit was organized for 51 project partners to Central Institute of Agricultural Engineering Bhopal to learn about pre and post harvest technologies easy to operate agricultural tools and implements for reducing the time in various agricultural practices linking up with renewable energy technologies
Regular guidance is provided to the Regional Coordinators and CEE teams on how to do the handholding and guidance to the NGOsCBOs on analyzing GEF impacts institution building in projects and how to assess the measurable impacts
Support provided to Sarjana who has developed indigenous rice varieties to label them with quality ingredients and link them with markets More than 250 kgs of Rice sold through network benefitting 23 farmers

description.narrative: To ensure a mosaic of land uses and community practices across the rural landscape to generate sustainable livelihoods and global benefits for BD LD and CCM
Number of hectares of land brought under sustainable land and resource management in the Western Ghats WG Himalayan Front HF and Arid and SemiArid Regions ASAR

comment.narrative: 0 ha
200000 hectares

Against a grant allocation of US 1100 million for biodiversity conservation a budget commitment of US 1070 has been done through 35 projects
Presently Biodiversity conservation and use is happening in 78948 hectares in WG HF ASAR in eastern and central India
Nearly 871 villages 80000 households are impacted directly and the technology and process spread is happening naturally in neighbouring kinship areas Several projects are in protected and community conserved areas working with tribal people
Regular guidance is provided through a series of Guidance Workshops and by organizing regular Market Places Green Haats to link the biodiversity products to markets
Western Ghats In WGs nearly 323 villages impacted Vechur Trust collaborated with University of Veterinary and Animal Sciences in making improved local breed semen available for breeding of Vechur cows which is supplied to 4 centres Nearly 1100 households have been approached through various trainings in the conservation of the breed MNTN has now been active in promoting the integration into other 10 Panchayats of the Malabari Goat Conservation project Nearly 200 women Groups linked to NABARD and local breed conservation to Malabari SEVA has been promoting the conservation of Vembur sheep in 10 Panchayats Innovation of community led mangrove conservation in 100 ha with 4 different varieties
More than 18 new products established by KFI based on the local biodiversity eg Brown Rice Honey turmeric powder red chillies etc PLANT has built 200 artificial structures for Reef Management increasing marine biodiversity and fish breeding for alternate livelihood measures Shashwat has increased and focussed on fish biodiversity with 4 ornamental fish
In Arid and Semi Arid Regions In ASAR nearly 358 villages are impacted In many projects like SSE 20 core and 10 dissemination villages Sarjana 3015 Sujagriti 720 SYSS 710 SRIDA 1010 GVSS 510 Samarthak Samiti 925 more than 30000 ha area is directly impacted through women SHGs in conservation of local protected areas new plantations of Bamboo Guggal Neem Satavar and PlashTamrind grown
Himalayan Front In HF nearly 190 villages are impacted In Bioved 50 beneficiaries from 11 NGO partners had training in lac production decorative dyes scientific methods of lac cultivation They trained on 1000 lac host plants in 40 ha and later 11 NGOs taking up in 5000 ha In Bihar Development Trust BDT 20 farmers growing 3 varieties in 20 ha land listing 25 women SHGs 250 women engaged in developing 22 artisans and linking markets for 27 new products In Lotus in 45 villages 120 farmers are conserving 18 different varieties over an area of 350 ha in 18 villages Linking some varieties to markets
200000 hectares

Against a grant allocation of US 1100 million for biodiversity conservation a budget commitment of US 1070 has been done through 35 projects
Presently Biodiversity conservation and use is happening in 78948 hectares in WG HF ASAR in eastern and central India
Nearly 871 villages 80000 households are impacted directly and the technology and process spread is happening naturally in neighbouring kinship areas Several projects are in protected and community conserved areas working with tribal people
Regular guidance is provided through a series of Guidance Workshops and by organizing regular Market Places Green Haats to link the biodiversity products to markets

More than 18 new products established by KFI based on the local biodiversity eg Brown Rice Honey turmeric powder red chillies etc PLANT has built 200 artificial structures for Reef Management increasing marine biodiversity and fish breeding for alternate livelihood measures Shashwat has increased and focussed on fish biodiversity with 4 ornamental fish
In Arid and Semi Arid Regions In ASAR nearly 358 villages are impacted In many projects like SSE 20 core and 10 dissemination villages Sarjana 3015 Sujagriti 720 SYSS 710 SRIDA 1010 GVSS 510 Samarthak Samiti 925 more than 30000 ha area is directly impacted through women SHGs in conservation of local protected areas new plantations of Bamboo Guggal Neem Satavar and PlashTamrind grown
Himalayan Front In HF nearly 190 villages are impacted In Bioved 50 beneficiaries from 11 NGO partners had training in lac production decorative dyes scientific methods of lac cultivation They trained on 1000 lac host plants in 40 ha and later 11 NGOs taking up in 5000 ha In Bihar Development Trust BDT 20 farmers growing 3 varieties in 20 ha land listing 25 women SHGs 250 women engaged in developing 22 artisans and linking markets for 27 new products In Lotus in 45 villages 120 farmers are conserving 18 different varieties over an area of 350 ha in 18 villages Linking some varieties to markets

description.narrative:
Amount of new and additional financial resources leveraged for community driven sustainable resource management in India
Improvement in Systemic Level Indicators of Capacity Development Scorecard Annex 3

comment.narrative: USD 5 million

Against the total OP5 grant commitment of US 2445381 so far a cofinancing of US 4798986 196 has been linked up by the NGOsCBOs as inkind and incash contributions through government schemes Forest Livestock Agriculture and Watershed Departments banks and rural credits
Also nearly 250000 USD have been sourced from MoEFCC UNDP and private sector sources By the end of the project we will be able to fully achieve the target
USD 5 million

Against the total OP5 grant commitment of US 2445381 so far a cofinancing of US 4798986 196 has been linked up by the NGOsCBOs as inkind and incash contributions through government schemes Forest Livestock Agriculture and Watershed Departments banks and rural credits
Also nearly 250000 USD have been sourced from MoEFCC UNDP and private sector sources By the end of the project we will be able to fully achieve the target

description.narrative: tons of carbon emission reductions achieved through SGP interventions

comment.narrative: 200000 metric tonnes per year of CO2e
75000 metric tonnes of CO2e per year reduced

Nearly 79450 MTs of CO2e have been reduced through 27 projects by adopting measures like fuelefficient cookstoves biogas units protection and plantation of mangroves carbon sequestration SRI techniques enrichment plantations biomass briquettes large fuelefficient cookstoves solar technologies and water harvesting are simultaneously improving the livelihoods of the poor and marginalized communities
In projects like Manuvikasa 50 large size cookstoves Peermade 50 large cookstoves GSMT 500 cookstoves Vikas Samarthan 50 biogas CORE Flyash Bricks 390 toilets SYSS 250 cookstoves PK Thampan 60 biogas Kurseong Disha PPSS for plantations over 300 hac is helping to reduce CO2 emissions
In most of the projects the actions are encouraged through women SHGs and locals are encouraged to take decisions and communities contribute 2540 costs in technology uptake In each of the project nearly 23 persons are trained in the upkeep of the technology repairmaintenance Links of locals provided to Service Providers Projects like Sarthak plastic recycling 700 MTspa and Hunnarshala 100 MTs solid waste management are contributing to CO2 emission reduction
75000 metric tonnes of CO2e per year reduced

Nearly 79450 MTs of CO2e have been reduced through 27 projects by adopting measures like fuelefficient cookstoves biogas units protection and plantation of mangroves carbon sequestration SRI techniques enrichment plantations biomass briquettes large fuelefficient cookstoves solar technologies and water harvesting are simultaneously improving the livelihoods of the poor and marginalized communities
In projects like Manuvikasa 50 large size cookstoves Peermade 50 large cookstoves GSMT 500 cookstoves Vikas Samarthan 50 biogas CORE Flyash Bricks 390 toilets SYSS 250 cookstoves PK Thampan 60 biogas Kurseong Disha PPSS for plantations over 300 hac is helping to reduce CO2 emissions
In most of the projects the actions are encouraged through women SHGs and locals are encouraged to take decisions and communities contribute 2540 costs in technology uptake In each of the project nearly 23 persons are trained in the upkeep of the technology repairmaintenance Links of locals provided to Service Providers Projects like Sarthak plastic recycling 700 MTspa and Hunnarshala 100 MTs solid waste management are contributing to CO2 emission reduction

description.narrative: Improvement in Systemic Level Indicators of Capacity Development Scorecard Annex 3

comment.narrative:
SYSTEMIC LEVEL The baselines and targets against the following capacities to be assessed at the time of selecting individual grantees BL Tgt
1 Capacity to conceptualize and formulate local level policies actions on sustainable resource use
2 Capacity to implement programmes and action on sustainable resource use
3 Capacity to engage and build consensus among all stakeholders
4 Capacity to mobilize information and knowledge
5 Capacity to monitor evaluate and report and learn at the grantee and project levels

22 guidance workshops by the end of project
1 900 NGOs and CBOs by the end of the project
2 900 NGOsCBOs by the end of the project
3 10 Institutions and 500 NGOsCBOs by the end of project
410 institutions linked and 12 different technologies adopted by the end of project by the grantees
5 90 NGOCBO partners at the end of project have community capacities created in practicing twothree technologies

1 26 Guidance Workshops organized in OP5 10 workshops organized during one year at different Regions of the country 8 Regional Committee meetings organized total 16 RCMs done and total of 1204 proposals reviewed and only 77 approved also nearly 29 are in pipeline for better development the capacities of NGOsCBOs enhanced by arranging exposure visits to successful projects adopting tested technologies and linking them with government programs Departmental trainings as cofinancing and financial institutions to enhance the scope of project activities
2 Nearly 792 NGO members participated in these workshops on a range of issues The followup Guidance Workshops organized after each NSC helping NGOs to understand Results Based Monitoring reporting and how to develop uniform pattern of documentation and impactoriented advocacy material usage of Logos etc
3 145 NGOs linked to more than 14 national and State level institutions technologyservice providers The institutions linked are
1 Lac Research Station Ranchi
2 JNKVV agricultural University Jabalpur and Similarly other Agricultural Universities in States
3 Krishi Vigyan Kendras KVKs in the respective project districts
4 Organic Farming Board under GOI Ghaziabad
5 Fisheries Livestock Forest and Agricultural Departments and Renewable Energy depts in the respective states of the projects
6 MGIRI Wardha
7Seeds Division NBPGR ICARNew Delhi and its partner institutions like CIAE Bhopal and IGFRI Jhansi
8 Indian Institute of Science IISc Bangalore
9 National Medicinal Plant Board New Delhi
10 State Biodiversity Boards and State Medicinal Plant Boards in respective states
11 National Biodiversity Authority NBA Chennai
12 Fodder Research Stations Ministry of Agriculture GOI
13 Department of Science and Technology
Some examples are Lotus Society made to visit Lok Panchayat and learn about setting up SeedGrain Banks est practices adopted by Vruksh Prem on development of seed banks Conare on development of good quality fodder and Yerala Society to link up their products for marketing were shared and learning visits encouraged The 34 NGOs taken to Central Institute of Agricultural Engineering Bhopal and exposed to land conservation methods and modern agricultural equipments for adopting in projects
4 More than 65 NGOs linked to 9 different technologies eg cookstoves oilexpellers milletullers bamboo biogas units floating biogas units sickles harrows chaffcutters solar cookers heaters etc A special technology interface workshop on successful use and application of Biogas Units organized on 1st Nov 2014 and 25 NGO from different parts of the country participated and learnt about new and economical models of biogas units The pioneers in use of Biogas technologies including private sector invited to share details adopting different ways of managing the slurry Biogas and cow dung and explaining cost benefit of each mode Links to preharvest and postharvest technologies and value addition done Guidance and exposure provided to NGO partners like PLANT Mahatma Phule and CENSFOOD to access more CSR funds SRIDA Sujagriti Sarjana created BMCs and working with Jabalpur Agricultural University and State Biodiversity Boards Madhya Pradesh and Chhatisgarh States
5 Almost all 77 partners taking up 34 technologies with communities in an integrated manner The projects are taken up by developing institutions like Self Help Groups Farmers Groups Village Volunteering Groups etc involved in planning by linking up the local resources and the common community property
NGOsCBOs through adoption of new technologies have access to funds and mainstreamed with Government programs for availing better social and economic opportunities for creating policy influence in projects like PPSS MNTN CCD Samekit PLANT IIPM GSMT and KFI Nearly 45 Exchange and Learning Visits organized

description.narrative: 1. Number of National Project Steering Committee meetings held to approve Small Grant proposals 2. Number Regional Steering Committee meetings held to screen Small Grants Proposals 3. Number Capacity Building Workshops held for small grantees

comment.narrative: 1. Lands under sustainable resource management. 2. To reduce CO2 emission through energy efficient technologies. 3. Capacity building of NGO staff

1. Approximately 3000 Ha of land under sustainable land resource management 2. Approximately 5000 MT of C02 emission reduction through the upscaling projects. 3. More than 40 NGOs staff are capacitated on SGP implementation
Complete final closure activities and close the project.
The closure activities have been completed and the project is closed.
